This is the point of free markets/capitalism. The combined knowledge of everyone in the world, even if any given individual has very little knowledge or only knowledge of a piece of the puzzle, is going to be far more effective at setting prices appropriately than some small group of government officials, no matter how well educated or how much of "experts" they are. This is why markets are so great - they are the purest form of democracy. If enough people think something is too expensive, they will refuse to buy it, and the sellers will be forced to lower the prices in order to cover their costs. If many people consider the price to be worth it, then the price will remain the same. If most people are willing to pay at that price and even higher, because the product is highly demanded, then the price will rise. Generally, even if the government-sanctioned experts do have legitimate expertise, they have been hand-selected out of a pool of experts with varying opinions, because their particular opinion will back up what the state already wants to do. They will be chosen because of their opinion which agrees with the state, and anyone who disagrees is opposing "science" or "the experts". It's a very effective, but ultimately not logically sound, political weapon for oppressing the critics.

0:46 I actually think it's impressive that by this chart there were about as many "analog" photographs taken in 2010 ish as there were taken in 1968 ish. I would have thought the 2010 number would be MUCH lower!. BTW As a photog who "worked" both eras, I don't call the "film" age "analog" I don't even use the term "film" era, as a LOT of pre-electronic photos were NOT on film, but often metal or glass plates. The sensor and recording media is the difference. The terms I use are CHEMICAL photography and ELECTRONIC photography, ANALOG electronic photography also exists (The ORIGINAL Sony Mavica was Electronic AND analog). Before digital had decent quality AND were affordable, I shot on film (chemical sensor), but had the images processed as CDs or as "real" prints and then scanned. That's HYBRID photography. Yeah, Nerdy, I know.

The wisdom of crowds is usually dependant on the first guesser's guess; people tend to herd towards answers deemed popular, so estimate closer to what those before them wstimated. If the first guesser was way off, it's unlikely that the average will be accurate. The exception is if no-one knows the others' answers, in which case it's fine.

The same question works with videos: how big would be a screen as big as the sum of all the screens that ever played the images of the Armstrong's landing on the moon or Luther King's iconic speech? Or Gamgam style...

Veins are closer to the surface than arteries, so we only see veins. Blood is neither always red nor always blue. All arteries, except the pulmonary artery, carry oxygen-rich blood which is bright red. We don't see it because it is deep under the surface. All veins, except the pulmonary vein, carry de-oxygenated blood which is red-purple. We see it because it is close to the surface.
Veins are closer to the surface because they collapse when cut, whereas arteries don't.

Vein color is determined in large part by the color of venous blood, which is usually dark red (and not blue as is commonly believed) as a result of its low oxygen content. Actually, it's like this.  What makes blood red is, of course, oxygen.  Obviously, this means that blood in our blood vessels is red, because if it were blue, that would mean that there's no oxygen in it, which would be bad.  So the blood in our arteries and capillaries is red.  But the blood in our VEINS, which has dumped its oxygen and is heading back to the heart to be replenished, has no oxygen, so it IS blue.  That's why your veins are blue.

As for the getting slower the longer they are used for, when using an HDD, your hard drive can get clutterd or "fragmented" This is when little bits of data from a single file are spread all over the disk. Fragmented hard drives can slow down your computer, but you can get special programs to de-fragment your HDD.

The longer you use your laptop, the more programs there are running in the background. Pressing X does not always close programs. Restarting your computer ends these applications, freeing up memory and CPU resources. Press CTRL ALT DEL, go to task manager and look at how many processes are running in the background. I bet you will see a bunch. There are ways to manage your resources so you don't have to restart your pc. do a quick google search on it.

Laptops are fast when first started because memory stacks and heaps aren't allocated yet, and running background processes don't have to remove old allocated memory in order to create their own space until the stack/heap reaches a certain point. After awhile, drives become fragmented, meaning pieces of leftover files are hidden within your harddisk just taking up space and not being used by the system. You can defrag your computer (on a PC) in the control panel somewhere.

by the way 'colour spectrum' has nothing to do with this as a lot of people are suggesting. spectrum makes a colour, but your body 'reacts' to the photons that are hitting your retina, controlling the image we see, which I 'think' is what you were more asking about :p
I have been asking myself the exact question myself!

yes, we can be sure of it, In your eyes there are cells that detect your 'hi-res' pictures called 'cone cells' these cone cells can only detect 3 different colours, Yellow, Green and Blue. every other colour is created from those 3 colours that are in everyone's retina. The other cells in your eye are 'Rods' these are only used mainly for seeing in the dark, and are most dense on the outer edges in the retina, that's why you can see better out of your peripherals in the dark. Hope that helps :)

Ultimately that's a philosophical question, simply because science has no straight answer for it. It seems that the perception of colors is the same for everyone, but no one knows exactly how the visual system calibrates itself. However it is accepted that some variations may occur from one person to another. In short, it's unlikely that my red is your blue, and your blue is someone's green, but it is plausible that my red may be a little less saturated than yours or vice-versa.

When you itch, complex, prostaglandins, histamine and a few other key inflammatory mediators are released. Chemotaxis (mediators following a chemical gradient) brings other cells and chemicals to reduce the stimulus (inflammation). You itch a scratch as through operant conditioning you have learnt that scratching resolves it. This occurs by overriding the itch sensation with nociception (pain) as your spine is not good at sending 2 signals to your brain at once (gate control theory).

In schools they call it a grading curve. "Example if there are three grades, A, B and C, where A is reserved for the top 10% of students, B for the next 20%, and C for the remaining 70%, then scores in the percentile interval from 0% to 70% get grade C, scores from 71% to 90% get grade B, and scores from 91% to 100% get grade A." It's both good and bad, good if you want to be a mediated student, also takes out the idea that if all the students failed it then it's scaled down.

Let explain the mistake here... The video implies that photography has been around since 1826, or for around 186 years. The video also implies that 4 billion is the maximum number of photographs taken in a year so far in recorded history. However, 4 billion times 186 does not give you anywhere close to 3.5 trillion, the total amount of photographs given in the video. In fact, if mankind had taken pictures at a rate of 4bil per year for 500 years the total would still not reach 3.5 tril.

"Wisdom of the Crowds" is a misleading term.
There is no "wisdom" in huge crowds. It's rather a "Higher statistically chance of guessing right of the crowds".
A good example are Tea Party supporters in the US. They are a crowd. Statistically, their collective estimation would be more accurate than the estimation of their individuals; but that doesn't mean they are wise at all. 
That is why direct democracy isn't actually better than representative democracy. The crowd is a lot, but not wise.

I'm not Micheal though I hope I can answer your questions just as well. One googol is defined as 10^100. All particles in the observable universe can be accounted for to be roughly 10^80. However you need at least one particle to store one bit and every letter consists of 8 bits. Therefore it would be completely impossible to store more than about 10^79 letters in the whole observable universe.
The information stored on the internet is about 4*10^21 bits.

The sum of that is what defines "you".

The 46 chromosomes in each of our cells' nuclei contain massive lengths of DNA. The DNA as you probably know is a double helix shape with lines crossing joining the two sides. There are bases along each side, these are given the letters G, C, T, A. Each of these bases join together, G to C and T to A, to form sections of the DNA that we call Genes. Genes are the instructions for what our body looks like. We have genes for eye colour, blood type, hair colour etc. :)
